text:
hello everyone, would you say an *actionable SEO guide for content marketers* of some sort, broken down into digestible chunks, be valuable to the content writing community? Or is this overdone?
Since COVID struck I've been volunteering to artists. Three months later i posted my learnings on linkedin (TLDR: SEO is completely ignored and they prefer the quick but short lived wins of social media). Surprisingly, two major groups of people i.e Developers and Content Marketers told me they also felt SEO is too confusing, expensive or boring to implement. Is that true?

text:
*Hot take incoming* :fire: *:*

I'd love to see somebody do it that actually has ranked things versus peddling the same jargon they've read on other blogs.

text: I'm just surprised SEO is something separate from content marketing when the whole idea is to have it discoverable. Is there a major painpoint Im missing?

elements.text: I'm just surprised SEO is something separate from content marketing when the whole idea is to have it discoverable. Is there a major painpoint Im missing?

text: Honestly? Lots of the gurus making it super complicated to sell SEO courses. :man-shrugging:

elements.text: Honestly? Lots of the gurus making it super complicated to sell SEO courses.

text: Also, it's one of the few "black box" channels where we know some of the major inputs, and then the output, but can't track it directly

elements.text: Also, it's one of the few "black box" channels where we know some of the major inputs, and then the output, but can't track it directly

text:
SEO isn’t complicated, but it is expensive (either in time or dollars or both). Combined with the ‘black box’ Brendan mentioned, it’s hard to convince smaller brands and individuals that it’s worth it. Full SEO means:

• creating content that walks the line of optimization and reader interest (a *lot* of content)
• investing in a backlink campaign to specific pages and across the site
• technical review of on-page and off-page SEO issues
For <http://Wiza.co|Wiza.co>, for example, I’ve spent 4 months and $15k to bring traffic from 3k/mo to 9k/mo.

text: Search-engine discoverable content is also just one element of content marketing strategy and execution. As <@U014RK24F9D> says, it tends to be pretty resource-intensive and if you’re already struggling to just create and measure the success of content period, which is where a lot of companies get stuck, then SEO can seem insurmountable.

text: <@UUXMCJQ15> That’s organic search traffic, right. The ultimate goal is conversions, so it’s a matter of balancing BOFU content (low volume keywords) with TOFU content (high volume keywords). We’ve seen our conversion rate drop a point as we start bringing in traffic from high volume keywords.

elements.text: That’s organic search traffic, right. The ultimate goal is conversions, so it’s a matter of balancing BOFU content (low volume keywords) with TOFU content (high volume keywords). We’ve seen our conversion rate drop a point as we start bringing in traffic from high volume keywords.

text: SEO is also just slow compared to many other efforts. We're actually prepping to publish a post rn that looks at how it grows exponentially over time, and you won't see results fast but if you invest the same amount of money in paid/SEO then due to exponential growth SEO will far outpace paid (plus it doesn't go away when you stop paying for it). I think a lot of companies are scared of efforts where they can't see immediate results

text:
It sounds like the guide you're describing is specifically _not_  for content marketers, but rather for subject matter experts who could maybe extend their reach by paying just a little more attention to search, is that right? or did I misread this? :sweat_smile:

An SEO guide for content marketers feels overdone. An SEO guide for people who just have some valuable stuff to say and want to not completely mess it up in search feels like a very fresh angle.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
It'd be cool to see how you tackle this <@U0153M0K2N7> for content marketers specifically, because I just assumed it was a truth universally acknowledged that SEO and Content Marketing are like PB&J
Chuckled <@UUXMCJQ15>'s burn. I have created long term SEO content campaigns that resulted in a pretty good traffic growth to a blog (from 5K to 100K in monthly traffic). 100% believe in SEO, although I gotta say a well-thought out distribution strategy is killer too especially for a low DA site

text: <@U014FMGRKQA> I speak frankly to my CEO about my limitations because I'm the only marketer on the team. I express my strengths to him and let him know that I can create landing pages, redesign the blog, and make infographics, but it will take me longer than a pro developer or graphic designer and that time will take away from my other main job functions.  He gave me a larger budget for freelancers and agency help in response. I also discussed a role title change or a little job crafting to represent what I actually do. I'll let you know how that goes :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I speak frankly to my CEO about my limitations because I'm the only marketer on the team. He gave me a larger budget for freelancers and agency help in response. I also discussed a role title change or a little job crafting to represent what I actually do. I'll let you know how that goes

text: I would go with <@U01340H0VD5> suggestion of relevant partners. For example, we're an accounting service but our audience is business owners not accountants so we partner with relevant services like payroll and financial reporting software like Gusto, QB Online and Divvy.

elements.text: I would go with

suggestion of relevant partners. For example, we're an accounting service but our audience is business owners not accountants so we partner with relevant services like payroll and financial reporting software like Gusto, QB Online and Divvy.

text:
wow everyone, thank you! So from everyone's replies, its rather different from what I heard at first. From what I heard, content marketers are NOT doing SEO. Its something separate; i.e I'm a content marketer who will work with your SEO specialist or give me the keywords and I'll do the writing. It is vastly different from someone who is strategising and crafting the whole journey for conversions with content marketing, say I'd do all the keyword/topic research THEN create a content strategy THEN write the content, plus taking all the other elements of content strategy into consideration. I thought that would be the natural thing to do! (of course in larger companies its not always the case but this is what I feel is the ideal)
 So it sounds like its NOT difficult nor complicated, but rather most of you think its too resource intensive and the time spent is disproportionate to the results. Tell me if i'm understanding that wrong.  Like <@UUVRDR2QY> and her results,  I've always thought it goes hand in hand without question. I would never ever ask any client to create ANY content without thinking of the almost sure win seo strategy. As an SEO person i understand your pain on the cost :sweat_smile: <@U014RK24F9D>
So perhaps a guide is unnecessary, or are many guides out there just :shit:? . I thought SEO needed demystifying of some sort, but glad its now back to same old problems of it just being slow and expensive :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
